name: More Interesting Trials Through History Quiz | World | 10 Questions

questions.text: The Dreyfus Affair was a scandal that resulted in Dreyfus being sent to Devil's Island. Of what crime was he accused?
questions.explanation:
Selling State Secrets.

	They said that he sold secrets to the Germans. But, did he do it?

questions.text: Al Capone, Chicago gangster extraordinaire, ultimately ended up in prison. Of what crime was he convicted?
questions.explanation:
Income Tax Evasion.

	Ironic, isn't it?

questions.text: The Salem Witch Trials were a disturbing part of American History. When did they occur?
questions.explanation:
Late 1600's.

	1692 is the date usually given.

questions.text: Oscar Wilde went to prison after his trial went against him. What major work did he write while incarcerated?
questions.explanation:
'De Profundis'.

	'De Profundis' is a long, memoir-style essay. 'Gray' and 'Earnest' were from better days. Kipling wrote 'Light'

questions.text: Which of these individuals participated in the Scopes trial?
questions.explanation:
William Jennings Bryan.

	Bryan - opposed by Clarence Darrow.

questions.text: What was the crime for which Socrates was put on trial?
questions.explanation:
Corruption of Youth.

	There were a lot of issues and motives behind the scenes.

questions.text: Joan of Arc was tried as a heretic (and ultimately burnt at the stake). When did her trial take place?
The Impeachment of Andrew Johnson was prompted (in part) by his dismissal from office of this individual:
questions.explanation:
Edwin Stanton.

	It was Stanton. Chase presided over the proceedings.

questions.text: Which prisoner actually suffered the penalty that was imposed on them by the Nuremberg court?
questions.explanation:
Albert Speer.

	Goering committed suicide before he could be executed. Bormann was condemned to death - but was never taken into custody. Mengele was not a defendant. Speer was sentenced to prison - and served time in Spandau.

questions.text: Which co-defendant was also a member of the Rosenberg family?
questions.explanation:
David Greenglass.

	Sobell and Gold were defendants, but not family members. Kaufman, I believe, was the judge.It was Greenglass who was Ethel Rosenberg's brother.
